item.description:
The Ann Arbor Chronicle has appeared on the scene.  Here are some early reviews. The Vassar Miscelleny of 1872 writes: The Yale Literary Magazine opines:
The Yale Literary Magazine  By Yale University Finally, the Hamilton Literary Magazine has its say in 1885:
Hamilton Literary Magazine  By Hamilton College (Clinton,  N.Y.) Early reviews are priceless.  Best of luck to the new editorial team.

item.title: Farmer's Market report for late August 2008
item.description: Every single thing you might possibly want to eat is ripe.  Enjoy. (Stock up for February.)

item.title: Homeless Dave interview on MLive.com
item.description: There’s a very fun interview of Dave Askins online - his blog Teeter Talk is must reading. WHOis: David Askins

item.title: paper, plastic, or burlap? on plastic bag bans
item.description: I've been collecting information about bans on plastic bags, with an eye towards the Ann Arbor City Council's discussion of banning disposable plastic bags here in town. Bob Lilienfeld from Use Less Stuff has a good and thorough paper vs. plastic lifecycle research analysis to understand some perspective on the levels of tradeoffs involved in the decision. municipalities with bag ban laws, passed or not Cities with bag bans: San Francisco, CA - Plastics News coverage.

item.title: Ann Arbor Startup Weekend, June 20-22 2008
item.description:
Laura Fisher (and a cast of thousands) is organizing Ann Arbor Startup Weekend, June 20-22 2008 in downtown Ann Arbor.
There's a nice story in the Ann Arbor News about the event; I'll excerpt:
The intent of the event, which has been held in several cities throughout the country, is to start the weekend with no formal business plans and emerge a few days later with a couple of real companies.

item.title: Scio Residents for Safe Water and the Pall/Gelman dioxane plume
item.description:
Scio Residents for Safe Water will be at the Ann Arbor Green Fair on Friday, June 13, 2008. They have been tracking the dioxane contamination associated with the Pall/Gelman site - see map above, which links to the Washtenaw County government PDF.
Previous discussion on this on Vacuum from 2004, and it's not getting any better.

item.title: Ann Arbor May 6 2008 election results and AutoMARK voting issues
item.description: I'll link to election results when they go online here. The Washtenaw County site has the official results. The Ann Arbor News has coverage on the blog, but, true to form, they don't link to the official results site in their coverage. Early returns (63% counted at 9:30pm) have both Ann Arbor millage proposals passing 3-1, and incumbent school board member Helen Gates-Bryant leading 2-1. Voter turnout looks like it's going to be less than 10% county wide.

item.title: Burns Park Run 2008
item.description: I walked the 5k - official time 39:47 (a 12:49 pace). Lots of fun! More details and link to race results when it's online. UPDATE: Burns Park Run 2008 results are up! Searchable complete results (789 finishers), 10K run, 5K run, 5K walk. The official race site for the Burns Park Run is where the race results will be. Some race photos from Mae's Real Stories and The Corkys. This movie has the course sped up to 5 minutes - it's a terrific route.

item.title: Ann Arbor City Code: littering
item.description: in our series on relevant parts of the city code, here’s the piece that lets you quote chapter and verse when some part of your walk to town goes past a building littered with soggy 3+ day old newspapers. Chapter 82 LITTERING AND DISTRIBUTION OF HANDBILLS 7:103. Owner to maintain premises free of litter, handbills and newspapers. The owner or person in control of private property shall at all times maintain the premises free of litter, handbills or more than three days accumulation of newspapers.

item.title: LA2M - Lunch Ann Arbor Marketing - Wednesday at Eastern Flame
item.description: Derek Mehraban organized the first weekly Wednesday downtown Ann Arbor lunch for people in the marketing world at Eastern Flame on Ashley next to the Fleetwood Diner. He’s calling it LA2M. You can see what a QSL card for LA2M looks like from the 1920s. Derek, if you want to print a sticker, you have a design ready-made. There were 12 for lunch for the first event, and the restaurant obliged with a soup and sandwich for $5 special.

item.title: Galbi tang at Maru - new Korean restaurant where Seoul Korner used to be
item.description: Bob, Kim, Margaret and I went out for lunch at Maru today. Bob and Margaret had the bi bim bop, and Kim had a bento with spicy chicken (and a side of macaroni). I had the galbi tang, a big bowl of steaming delicious beef short rib soup for $9. We talked about a bunch of things, and it was pleasant. Maru is about $1 or $2 per dish more than Seoul Korner was, and for that extra you get table service, somewhat bigger portions, more banchan (we had 4 for 4 people), and a broader menu.
